name: Baccarat Chemin de Fer
description: A variant of the card game baccarat, central to the plot of 'Casino Royale'.

content.title: Overview
content.body: Baccarat Chemin de Fer is a traditional French card game and one of the main types of baccarat, played primarily in European casinos. It is a game of chance and strategy where players bet on the outcome of a dealer’s and player’s hands.

content.title: Appearance
content.body: The game is typically played with six or eight decks of cards on a large table with designated areas for players, the banker, and various betting options. The cards are dealt face down, enhancing the suspense for both players and spectators.

content.title: Function in the Story
content.body: In 'Casino Royale,' baccarat Chemin de Fer provides the narrative framework for the central conflict, as James Bond must defeat Le Chiffre in this high-stakes game to bankrupt him and foil his terrorist financing schemes.

content.title: Game Mechanics
content.body: Unlike other baccarat versions, the player can actually take turns being the banker, adding a strategic layer. Players decide whether to draw an additional card based on the value of their first two cards, with the winning hand closest to nine.

content.title: Story Significance
content.body: The game’s tension and psychological warfare are central to the novel's dramatic pacing, showcasing Bond’s composure, skill, and ability to manage high-pressure situations.
